metadata.title: Temporomandibular Disorders
anatomical location body part affected: Jaw and temporal bone/ temporomandibular joint (TMJ), dentition, and jaw muscles
description: Temporomandibular disorders (TMD) is a collective term for clinical problems that are characterized by chronic or fluctuating orofacial pain related to internal derangement and/or articular dysfunction of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), masticatory muscles, and closely related structures. Physical examination often reveals reduced mouth opening, increased tension in muscles of mastication (i.e., masseter, anterior temporalis, and pterygoids) and TMJ crepitus or a clicking noise in patients with TMD(1,5,16)
15% to 25% of the population will experience TMD at some point in their lives(15)

Surgical treatment for TMD is rare and only considered when conservative treatment has failed. Patients with disc displacement without reduction may undergo arthroscopy or a total joint replacementto decrease pain and improve function. Moderate evidence indicates that a variety of nonoperative treatments (i.e., patient education, behavior modification, biofeedback, physical therapy, pharmacotherapy, occlusal therapy [oral appliances/splints], acupuncture, and cognitive behavioral therapy) are effective for relief of pain and muscle tension, and for improving masticatory function(1)
Physical therapy typically involves superficial heat, ultrasound, soft-tissue  work, jaw exercises, biofeedback, cervical posture training, and patient education(15,23)

ICD-10-CA.base: modification in Canada, K07.6 subdivided to identify

ICD-10 codes.M26.29: other specified disorders of temporomandibular joint
ICD-10 codes.M24.9: joint derangement, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No special agencies are applicable for this condition. TMDs are common conditions in litigation in cases of facial trauma or dental malpractice.Inquire about any ongoing legal claims
presentation signs and symptoms: Pain, tenderness, and tightness in surrounding soft tissues of the jaw and neck
Headache, ear pain, dizziness, tinnitus, dysphagia, and spinal pain may occur
Oral pain and dysfunction might interfere with eating, talking, singing, etc.
Symptoms may be worse during stressful life events(15) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Etiology usually is uncertain. Contributory factors include(1,15)–Myofascial pain-dysfunction  syndrome is the most common and may include bruxism, masticatory muscle dysfunction,poor cervical posture, prolonged mouth opening, myofascial pain, and neuropsychological factors–Emotional stress often precedes myofascial pain dysfunction, which accounts for 85% of all cases of TMD–Internal TMJ derangement and/or displacement of TMJ articular disc as a result of chronic dislocations–Iatrogenic mandibular malalignment secondary to occlusal appliance or orthodontic treatment
Less common causes include whiplash and trauma (e.g., blow to the chin), infection, rheumatologic conditions, tumors, andanatomical anomalies(49)
pathogenesis diagnostic classifications: Subgroups of TMD include patients with orofacial pain associated with(16)–Jaw muscle dysfunction characterized by painful articular movements–Articular disc displacement-Permanent or with reduction to normal position (usually on full opening)-Disc repositioning is usually accompanied by clicking joint sound-Anatomical abnormalities include a deep mandibular fossa, steep articular slope, and/or small condyle-Pain is associated with acute retrodiscal inflammation or chronic end-range  stretching of ligamentous structures-Acute anterior disc dislocation with inflammation is more painful than chronic stretch-The end range of motion of opening jaw may be decreased to only 25 mm. Normal jaw opening is 40–50 mm(1)–TMJ arthralgia, arthritis, or arthrosis associated with:-Inflammatory and/or degenerative changes in fibrous cartilage covering condyle-Exostoses and erosive irregularities of the temporal surface-Adhesions between temporal and cranial surface of disc-Irregularities of upper surface of disc; loss of elastic properties of supporting ligaments; perforation of retrodiscal tissues

The American Academy of Orofacial Pain categorizes TMD either articular or muscular based on anatomic origin oforofacial pain(15,16)–The articulating surfaces are the condylar process of the mandible and the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone; the articulardisc is between the two. The TMJ is a true synovial, diarthrotic joint capable of two actions of movement: rotational andtranslational(15)–Articular disorders of TMJ-Ankylosis-Congenital or developmental disorders-Disc derangement-Fracture of condylar process-Inflammatory disorders-Osteoarthritis-TMJ dislocation–Masticatory muscle disorders-Unclassified local myalgia-Myofascial pain-Myofibrotic contracture-Myositis-Myospasm-Neoplasia
risk factors ,,,: Overuse – excessive mouth opening, as in singing, having dental work, or playing a wind instrument
Sex: females present for care more commonly than males, at ratios of 3:1 to 4:1
Rheumatologic and degenerative conditions involving the TMJ

Joint hypermobility–Investigators in Taiwan found a significant positive association between TMDs and joint hypermobility syndrome in alarge retrospective study published in 2015. Data from a total of 975,788 eligible patients were analyzed. A statisticallysignificant association was observed between joint hypermobility and TMDs, and it was noted that patients withdisc-related  TMDs are more likely to experience joint hypermobility than patients with TMDs without disc disorders(6)

High trait anxiety–Trait anxiety is the relatively enduring disposition to feel stress, worry, and discomfort–Investigators in China found that the prevalence of psychological distress measured using the Depression, Anxiety, andStress Scales–21  (DASS-21)  was significantly higher in patients with TMD in the myofascial pain subgroup than in thenon-myofascial  pain subgroup in a study involving 510 patients with TMD(5)–Researchers in Japan found that TMD symptoms were only weakly associated with trait anxiety in a study involving1,415 adolescents aged 11–15  years who self-reported  their TMD symptoms(7)

overall contraindications precautions: Cardiovascular symptoms such as angina pectoris or myocardial infarction may manifest in atypical patterns, particularly in women. Any patients complaining of facial pain that is described as a sudden onset of intermittent burning, tingling, or pressure unrelated to jaw function in the presence of relevant cardiac history or signs should be referred immediately for medical screening Blood pressure and pulse should be part of the physical therapy systems screen
Evidence is lacking to support occlusal adjustment surgery (i.e., removal of teeth that might prevent a normal bite) (16)
Oral appliances worn continuously for months might create permanent bite changes that increase symptoms(1)
Refer to physician if there is suspicion of neoplasm or fracture
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: The onset is usually insidious with an unclear mechanism. Occasionally, TMD might develop following trauma (e.g., whiplash injury) or a prolonged dental procedure. In most cases, patients present with a chronic condition involving several components of temporomandibular anatomy

course of treatment.medical management: Document the date of initial diagnosis of TMD. Orofacial pain is usually the primary complaint(1,21). Document any prior therapeutic interventions for this condition and whether they were effective or not
surgical management: Surgical management:  Reserved for severe, chronic cases (see Clinical Review…Temporomandibular Joint Disorder: Postsurgical Management ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000008530)
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury What medications have been prescribed? Are the medications being taken as prescribed and are they effectively controlling symptoms? NSAIDs, corticosteroids, anxiolytics (e.g., clonazepam [Klonopin]), cyclobenzaprine, acetaminophen, topical methyl salicylate,gabapentin, and muscle relaxants (e.g., diazepam [Valium]) are often prescribed(16) When compared with placebo in an RCT, the following medications were shown to be ineffective in improving pain incelecoxib, diclofenac, topical capsaicin, benzodiazepines(16) Diagnostic tests completed  (1,15,16)Transcranial radiographs including the panoramic, transorbital, and transpharyngeal open and closed positionsis helpful with meniscus involvement, but it is less accurate than MRI and is seldom performedis highly accurate in diagnosing TMD osseous derangementis the procedure of choice to show disk integrity and position as well as degenerative changes of the TMJ. MRI is 95% sensitive and 88% specific(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, cognitivebehavioral  therapy, biofeedback) and whether or not they help Acupuncture is increasingly used with myofascial TMD.(8) Systematic reviews indicate that acupuncture may be beneficial as an adjunctive treatment for shortterm  analgesia in TMD(8) Auriculotherapy (ear acupuncture) was found effective for the treatment of students with anxiety and TMDs in an RCT conducted in Brazil that involved 44 college students. The control group received sham treatment. Outcomes measured included anxiety (STAI scale), number of tender points, and EMG activity during temporal muscle contraction(9)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Pain and dysfunction might interfere with eating, talking, and other oral functions. Pain might increase in relation to dentistry, stress, or oral functions. Does patient do anything to ease the pain?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. A TMD can result in cervical pain, head pain, ear pain, and facial pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant versus intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Facial and/or jaw pain might be accompanied by a variety of symptoms, including clicking, popping, or grinding of the TMJ, locking or catching of the jaw, limited mouth opening, abnormal occlusal wear, headache, earache, dizziness, and/or cervical pain
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Pain primarily in the morning might indicate nighttime mouth clenching
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Does pain disturb sleep? Document number of wakings/night. In what position does patient sleep? Habitual sleeping in prone position has been associated with TMD.(10) Do symptoms require the patient to sleep in a preferred position or to use extra pillows? Does the patient wear a night guard? Does wearing the night guard decrease pain? -Investigators in China found that the prevalence of moderate to severe sleep disturbance is significantly greater in patients with TMD that is categorized as myofascial pain than in TMD patients with non-myofascial  pain(5)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -TMD may cause an occipital headache or exacerbate headache symptoms(1,21) -Researchers in Japan found that TMD symptoms were associated with other orofacial pain conditions and neck pain in children and adolescents(7)  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Check for presence of cervical spine disorders or arthritic/joint disorders that might indicate a systemic polyarthritic condition. Review medications that have been prescribed and discontinued
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders.Approximately 70% of the general population who report headaches also present with symptoms of TMD.(21) Patients with rheumatoid arthritis involving the TMJ often have bilateral symptoms(15)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Question about stress as it relates to pain. Question about oral activities that reproduce pain (e.g., chewing gum, nail biting, chewing hard versus soft foods, clenching and grinding of teeth, eating, talking, laughing, yawning)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Oral activities that require wide opening of mouth (e.g., eating, talking, singing) might be affected. Inquire whether oral hygiene and/or usage of dentures are affected

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Activities of Daily Living (ADLs): Document which oral ADLs (i.e., that involve the mouth and/or face) are altered by TMD symptoms. Are any ADLs affected by headache or neck pain? •Joint mobility:  Assess mobility of cervical spine and the involved TMJ (compare to uninvolved TMJ)
observation inspection palpation includi: Evaluate opening pattern of jaw movement: Ask patient to open jaw slowly as wide as possible. Assess if opening is straight, lateral deviation to right or left, an “s” deviation, or other pattern. Assess closing/occlusal pattern(1,15,16)
Palpate TMJ for crepitus during mouth opening and closing. Document sounds as none, click, coarse crepitus, or fine crepitus(1,15,16)

The timing of the clicks might also be recorded as reproducible on opening, reproducible on closing, reproducible with reciprocal click, or nonreproducible click. This can be repeated for lateral excursion and protrusion

Palpate masticatory and associated muscles at rest, including anterior temporalis, masseter (origin, body, and insertion), posterior mandibular region (stylohyoid/posterior digastric), and submandibular region (medial pterygoid, suprahyoid, anterior digastric). During palpation, ask the patient about the presence of pain at the palpation site, whether palpation produces pain referral to a distant site, and whether palpation reproduces the pain the patient has been experiencing
Extra-oral  palpation has been found to have acceptable reliability, and use of a pressure algometer further improves reliability
The lateral pterygoid and temporalis tendon might be palpated intraorally with a gloved index finger, but this was not found to be reliable in untrained examiners
Ask patient to report level of pain experienced with palpation: 0 = no pain/pressure only, 1 = mild pain, 2 = moderate pain, 3 = severe pain
Palpation might also include the cervical spine, scalene, and sternocleidomastoid muscles, as indicated
Observe position of teeth on mouth closure: overbite, underbite, overjet (overbite with top incisors overlapping bottom incisors), etc.
Observe whether facial expressions are affected
Observe mobility of cervical spine during head movements
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess cervical posture for kyphosis (i.e., forward head position). Measure translation with a plumb line. Include evaluation of cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine. Check rib and shoulder symmetry
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Measure vertical ROM of mouth opening with millimeter ruler from edge of central incisor above and below. Record maximal unassisted opening without pain, maximum unassisted opening with any associated pain, and maximum assisted opening with any TMJ pain. Normal mean maximum unassisted opening is 52.9 mm for adult males and  45.4 for adult females, or about the width of the patient’s 2nd, 3rd, and 4th fingers. For functional activity 25 mm to 35 mm is needed.(11)

cryotherapy precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Over an area of recent hemorrhage or edema, or potential hemorrhage
In any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Stimulation through or across the chest
Cardiac pacemakers
Implanted stimulators
Over carotid sinuses
Uncontrolled hypertension/hypotension
Peripheral vascular disease
Thrombophlebitis
Pregnancy
Over pharyngeal area
Diminished sensation
Acute inflammation
Seizure history
Confused patients
Immature patients
Obesity
Osteoporosis
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
Over the eyes and testes
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present
In the area of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Over epiphyseal plates
During pregnancy, over the abdomen and low back
Over active bone growth at the epiphysis
Over a known or suspected area for cancer
Over the infected tissue in a tuberculosis infection
Over an area of active bleeding  can be used in area of hematoma
Over skin with impaired circulation  recommend use pulsed

Following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -Deep vein thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -Acute injury -Recently irradiated tissue -Impaired sensation due to nerve damage -Skin disease -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck
Metal implants, head, and heart often listed but consensus is there should not be contraindications
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
Over plastic or cemented implants
Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)
Over low back and abdomen during pregnancy
Over known or suspected area of malignancy
Over area of active bleeding

Following are considered contraindications but have no evidence to support -Myositis ossificans -Deep vein thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -Recently irradiated tissue -Implanted cardiac pacemaker or other implanted electronics -Reproductive organs -Eyes -Anterior neck
Over epiphysis with active bone growth
Over infected area
Over acute injury
Over area of impaired sensation due to nerve damage
With patients with impaired cognition or communication
Over areas of impaired circulation
In the presence of skin disease
Over plastic and cemented implants
Over spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves (poor evidence)
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions: (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy might be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(3)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications: do not use:(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: TMD/orofacial pain, mandibular dysfunction that interferes with oral ADLs, tenderness in soft tissues, loss of jaw ROM, headaches, education in behavior modification Rule out  (1,15,16) Temporal arteritis Toothache, dental conditions Referred pain from ear, sinus, parotid gland, or, rarely, eye Radicular cervical pain Angina Trigeminal neuralgia Condylar fracture/dislocation Neoplasm of jaw, salivary glands, or orofacial muscles Migraine headache Ramsey Hunt syndrome (zoster auricular syndrome)
prognosis: Prognosis is favorable in the vast majority of patients treated conservatively with a comprehensive treatment approach including pain control, restoration of normal muscle function, stress management, and behavior modification(16)
Although TMD often is chronic, symptoms might wax and wane
In most patients, symptoms will abate without intervention. Fifty percent of patients report improvement at 1 year and 85% by 3 years(16)
With conservative treatment, 75% of cases resolve within 3 months(16)

In a systematic review of literature on patients’ subjective perception of improvement of tinnitus before and after conservative TMD treatment, investigators found thatindividuals treated with a myorelaxant splint and therapies such as physical therapy and acupuncture were more likely to experience tinnitus remission than those treated with a myorelaxant splint alone(23)

Surgical intervention might be considered in the small percentage (less than 5%) of patients with recalcitrant pain and dysfunction accompanied by evidence of internal TMJ dysfunction and/or pathology(15)

In a retrospective cohort study, arthroscopic lysis and lavage surgery (AS) to decrease pain and improve maximum interincisal opening was successful in 62.3% of 247 TMD patients treated by a single surgeon from 2010 to 2015 in Massachusetts (24)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Dentist for oral disease that might indicate dental surgery Orthodontist for consult regarding oral braces/splint Acupuncturist (or other alternative pain management specialist) for intractable pain Clinical psychologist for cognitive behavioral therapy that involves progressive relaxation, abdominal breathing, and discussions of fear avoidance and pain behavior management issues(8) In an online survey of 256 dentists in Florida, 41% reported that they were unaware that physical therapists can treat TMD. Oral surgeons and orthodontists were more aware compared to other specialties(18)
other considerations: Authors of a meta-analysis  and systematic review found no significant difference in short-  or long-term  pain improvement between intracapsular injections of corticosteroids (CS) or sodium hyaluronate (NaH) for TMD. There was evidence that NaH was better than placebo(20)

Another systematic review and meta-analysis  showed that corticosteroid injections after arthrocentesis were superior to placebo in relieving pain but were inferior in increasing maximal mouth opening in the long term. Corticosteroid and hyaluronate injections without arthrocentesis decreased pain and improved maximal mouth opening. The corticosteroid group had an overall lower success rate than the hyaluronate group in the short term(22)

Authors of a retrospective cohort study in Turkey concluded that the stepped surgical treatment approach of arthrocentesis under local anesthesia as the first line of treatment followed by arthroscopic lysis and lavage under general anesthesia for unresolving cases was effective for internal derangement of TMJ with or without osteoarthritis(14)

In 2017, authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  found no relevant differences in outcomes between custom and stock TMJ surgical prosthetic devices(13)  –Twenty studies with 1262 patients who had a TMJ replacement surgery –Pre- and post-surgical  outcomes measured were maximal incisal opening, pain, diet, and function
treatment summary: Authors of a study in India found that ultrasound and phonophoresis were effective treatment modalities in patients with TMD(17) –Fifty patients with TMD were randomly assigned to an ultrasound (acoustic gel) group or a phonophoresis (acoustic gel with aceclofenac) group –Assessment of pain (V AS) and inflammation (C-reactive protein,CRP) were assessed before and after the 3 times per week for 2 weeks treatment –There was a significant decrease in V AS and CRP scores before and after treatment in both groups, with slightly superior scores in the phonophoresis group

Researchers of an RCT conducted in Brazil found that mobilization of the upper cervical spine and craniocervical flexor training decreased orofacial pain and headaches in women with TMD(21) –61 women with TMD were randomized into a control group (CG) or an intervention group (IG) –The CG received no intervention and the IG received suboccipital inhibition technique, passive AP upper cervical mobilization, sustained natural apophyseal glide (SNAG) for C1-C2  rotation, and craniocervical flexor stabilization exercise –The IG received 10 sessions over 5 weeks –Significant improvement in orofacial pain occurred at the fourth week of treatment

In a quasi-experimental  study in Brazil, physical therapy manual myofascial release and joint mobilization was assessed in 10 healthy subjects and 10 subjects with TMD through pain levels and EMG activity of the masseter and temporal muscles during maximum occlusion and chewing gum. There was no effect of manual therapy on EMG activity. There was pain level reduction in maximum occlusion and chewing gum after manual physical therapy(19)
Authors of a placebo-controlled  study in Brazil found that low-level laser therapy on the muscles of mastication was ineffective for treating young patients (14 to 23 years old) with TMD(4)

Self-care  might aid healing and prevent further injury. Self-care guided by the clinician includes modified oral rest (e.g., limiting mouth opening), applying moist heat or icing (as preferred), massaging affected jaw muscles, and gentle ROM jaw exercises(48,49) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain on palpation of TMJ and jaw muscles and with jaw movement _ _ Limited TMJ functions – jaw opening that affects eating (chewing, drinking, swallowing), yawning, speaking, laughingReduce/eliminate pain with functional jaw activities _ _ Reduce/eliminate palpable tenderness _ _ Improved mandibular ROM to within normal functional rangeModalities _ Ultrasound and phonophoresis are modalities that decrease pain and inflammation(50) _ _ _ Physical agents _ Ice and heat applications are frequently included in self-care education for TMD patients. Superficial heatmight have a palliative effect _ _ Manual therapy _ Accessory joint oscillatory mobilizations applied to the TMJ in transverse-medial, posterior-anterior, and longitudinal- cephalic directions. Trial of massage and muscle energy strain-counterstrain techniques applied to masticatory muscles _ _ Therapeutic exercises _ Active/assisted stretching _ Slowly open mouth to point of pain, and then open a little further using thumb and index finger to stretch. Can be performed as a hold/ relax or static stretch _ _ Stabilization _ Use index finger to provide light pressure to resisted motion in an isometric manner (no jaw movement) _ _ Manual mobilization _ Gentle, pain-free passive accessory motion to TMJ _ _ Coordination exercises/ neuromuscular control _ Open and close mouth slowly, with index finger on lateral pole of TMJ to control mandibular motion, while maintaining midline motion without asymmetry (use mirror) _ _ Splints _ Occlusive splints are frequently prescribed by dentists _ _ These can be repositioning splints or stabilization splints, and can be hard (acrylic) or soft. Flat plane repositioning splints have traditionally been used to reduce teeth grinding and treat the neuromuscular component of masticatory disorders _ _ Repositioning splints have the potential to cause irreversible occlusive changes and other problems. There is no evidence that occlusal adjustment improves or prevents TMDs(16) _N/A Educate patient that jaw clenching and certain oral habits might contribute to pain and dysfunction. Counsel about the nature of problem and prognosis _ _ Educate to reduce overuse/repetitive strain of the masticatory system by voluntary relaxation of jaw muscles. Counsel to recognize teeth clenching and avoid chewing (e.g., gum, hard foods), clenching pipe or cigar, nail biting, chewing on pencils, or leaning on the jaw _ _ Instruct patient in a home exercise program to complement the physical therapy exercise program and self massage and stretches of mastication muscles. Exercises should be progressed as the patient moves through phases of healing  Headache, ear pain, tinnitus, neck painReduce/eliminate associated pain and symptomsPostural training _ Cervical dysfunction and forward head posture is associated with TMDs. Cervical postural exercises might reduce pain and increased oral opening(21) _Progress as indicated and appropriateInstruct patient in postural exercises .

improved maximal pain-free opening of t: Measurement of mouth opening with a millimeter ruler

maintenance or prevention: Education that includes training in autorelaxation, breathing exercises, and work modification so that neck muscles are not stressed(12)
Undergo timely dental treatment and maintain good oral hygiene(11)
Use of mouth guard at night to prevent grinding(11)
Avoid wide, uncontrolled opening, such as yawning(16)
patient education: American Academy of Orofacial Pain, “TMD Patient Information Brochure” (pdf), http://www.aaop.org/content.aspx? page_id=22&club_id=508439&module_id=108085 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
